title: 114_hr403
content: The "Free Trade With Cuba Act" may be cited as the short title. The findings section is included in the Act. The Congress finds that Cuba is no longer a threat to the US, the embargo is counterproductive, and promoting trade can support democratic change in Cuba. On December 17, 2014, the President announced new steps to increase travel, commerce, and the free flow of information to Cuba, expressing interest in engaging Congress about lifting the embargo. The President announced steps to increase travel, commerce, and information flow to Cuba, expressing interest in lifting the embargo. The President announced steps to increase travel, commerce, and information flow to Cuba, expressing interest in lifting the embargo. The authorities under the Trading With the Enemy Act regarding Cuba will no longer be exercised, and export prohibitions under the Export Administration Act of 1979 will be removed. The President may impose new export controls with respect to Cuba under the Export Administration Act of 1979 or exercise authorities under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act in case of a national emergency. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, citing an unusual threat to national security, foreign policy, or the economy of the United States. Conforming amendments are made to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing certain sections and paragraphs from various acts, including the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing sections and paragraphs related to Cuba from various acts. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing sections and paragraphs related to Cuba, including the repeal of certain sections and the termination of denial of foreign tax credit with respect to Cuba. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exempt Cuba from the denial of foreign tax credit. Additionally, the Food Security Act of 1985's sugar quota prohibition is repealed. SEC. 4 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 5 pertains to travel. Travel to and from Cuba by US citizens or residents, and related transactions, may not be regulated if lawful in the US. Transactions include travel to/from Cuba, living expenses, and goods/services acquisition. The text chunk discusses the arrangements, promotions, or facilitation of travel to, from, or within Cuba, as well as transactions related to nonscheduled voyages and banking activities. The United States Postal Service will establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, utilizing charter providers if necessary. The President is urged to negotiate with the Government of Cuba to settle U.S. nationals' property claims and protect human rights. Effective date provisions are also included. The Act and its amendments will take effect 60 days after enactment.
